title: Raksha Bandhan
summary: Raksha Bandhan is a popular and traditional Hindu annual rite or ceremony, central to a festival celebrated in South Asia and other regions influenced by Hindu culture. On this day, sisters tie a rakhi (talisman) around their brothers' wrists, symbolically protecting them, receiving a gift, and investing brothers with a share of responsibility for their care. Observed on the last day of the Hindu lunar month of Shravana (typically August), the expression means "the bond of protection." Historically, the term also applied to a priest-patron ritual. The sister-brother festival, rooted in folk culture, is especially significant for married women due to the practice of village exogamy, often involving travel back to their natal homes.
key_points: A popular and traditionally Hindu annual rite/ceremony celebrated in South Asia and globally.
Sisters tie a rakhi (talisman/amulet) around their brothers' wrists.
The ritual symbolizes sisters' protection and brothers' shared responsibility for care, with a gift exchange.
Observed on the last day of the Hindu lunar month of Shravana, usually in August.
The expression "Raksha Bandhan" literally means "the bond of protection, obligation, or care."
Historically, the term also applied to a priest-patron ritual on the same day, predating the current sister-brother focus.
Holds special significance for married women, rooted in the practice of territorial or village exogamy.

Symbolic exchange of wishes for well-being and pledges of support.
current_status: Raksha Bandhan is a widely celebrated and popular Hindu annual festival, primarily focusing on the sister-brother bond. It continues to be observed across South Asia and by Hindu communities globally, maintaining its significance, especially for married women returning to their parental homes.
